title: [hardhat-flatten] Removing duplicated SPDX identifier
body: This issue is discussed also in `truffle-flattener` here https://github.com/nomiclabs/truffle-flattener/issues/55  and in this pull request https://github.com/nomiclabs/truffle-flattener/pull/61, But wanted to add it also directly in hardhat, since is the same issue with the `hardhat flatten` command.
Bump - this is really annoying when trying to deploy via e.g. Remix as it doesn't let you deploy like this right now. I'm on `Hardhat version 2.0.10`

Put a little bounty on this. What I'm looking for:
- Flattened files should only have ONE SPDX header. It could take the one from the main file OR optionally make this a config option. I like to keep the others as sometimes you're dealing with different licenses across files, so I rename the header to "License-Identifier: " (just remove the SPDX)
- Consolidate pragmas. Multiple "pragma experimental ABIEncoderV2;" declarations cause issues.
- Have a way to specify the output file(s). Currently I pipe it to a file but have to manually remove stuff from the top and bottom.
This should make it possible to automatically generate flattened files.

Also, I prefer to rename the headers instead of removing them, because I deal with projects where different files have different licenses. So since you already have done part of the work, if you also do renaming of license headers, removal of duplicate pragmas and either make the output non verbose or add ability to specify an output file (I keep having to remove lines from the top and bottom of the output), then I'm happy to pay out the bounty. Sorry @developerfred.

@boringcrypto Not sure what do you mean with "I prefer to rename the headers instead of removing them". 

The PR does two things:
- Remove licenses
- Add a custom license at the beginning of the flattened contract. It means that if you have multiple files each of them with a license, using `npx hardhat --license MIT` will remove **ALL** the licenses and will add `// SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT.`  at the beginning of the flattened file.

From the PR description:

```removeLicenses: Remove all licenses of the files to be flattened.
license: Add a unique license at the beginning of the file flattened. --license MIT will add // SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT.

Usage:

npx hardhat flatten --remove-licenses
npx hardhat flatten --license MIT
```

I can remove the abi-encoder v2 too. Will add it to the PR.

Specifying the output file can be easily done by using `>`: `npx hardhat flatten contract > myFlattenContract.sol` I don't think that  the output flag should be part of the PR. You can see an example [here](https://github.com/decentraland/wearables-contracts/blob/master/scripts/buildfull.sh#L20)
@fvictorio @boringcrypto I have added a new flag `unifyABIEncoderV2` to the [PR](https://github.com/nomiclabs/hardhat/pull/1223)

@boringcrypto No problem, I'll leave the task for you to add @nachomazzara  as a hunter.

I don't feel any of these should even be options. The function is called 'flatten', but the default behavior doesn't create a flattened version that compiles. So removing (or renaming) SPDX-License-Identifiers should be default behavior in my mind. And taking the SPDX of the main file and putting that at the top of the file. Removing compilation breaking pragmas should just be default. Who would NOT want this? So the only flag I envision is setting a new SPDX.

What is the use-case in which you want to create a file that you can't use?

If this functionality is too complex for core, then flatten shouldn't be in core at all in my mind. Make it into an extra package if you need to. But it would be great if using flatten would do as the name implies... take multiple solidity files and create a flattened version.

The primary use of flattened versions I see is to deploy from flattened versions instead of multi-file. Makes things look a lot better in Etherscan.

If it is it's own package, you could later extend it with cool features like tree-shaking, so you only get code that's actually used. I often do this manually now before final deployments.

Maybe you are right, but doing this in core would mean:

1. Introducing a breaking change (even if you feel confident that everyone would prefer the new behavior)
2. Adding more complexity that we'd need to maintain (we are _very_ understaffed right now)

I think a community plugin that "fixes" the flatten task in an opinionated way would be a great contribution to the Hardhat ecosystem. If anyone wants to tackle it, I'd be happy to assist.
Just one hint: there is no need to introduce a breaking change if it can be done by adding _flags_ as I proposed.

> Just one hint: there is no need to introduce a breaking change if it can be done by adding _flags_ as I proposed.

Yes, I think we are having two separate discussions here:

- Adding support for removing/consolidating licenses. This is what your PR does (with optional flags), and I think it looks pretty good. FWIW, I was already on the fence about adding that feature, but I'm inclined to think it can be merged.
- Adding support for merging duplicated pragmas, etc. This is where _I think_ we might be crossing a line. I understand the argument that non-compilable flattened files are useless; I think it's a strong point. But I don't think we want to add that level of complexity to core, at least right now. I believe that "the flatten task in core is pretty simple and straightforward, and if you want something more advanced you can use this third-party plugin" is the approach that would work for us the best.
Agree! I won't merge any pragma nor change any file by default. It is always easier to remove/deprecate an obsolete flag rather than change the core functionality of something.

I don't care much how you structure it. But the bounty is for a solution that somehow adds a working 'flatten' function to hardhat. If it's not in core, I guess a plug-in would do it. I do wonder what people are using the flatten for... my guess is that that everyone has their own small scripts or regexes to fix SPDX and other issues. Anyway, would be great if someone can fix this 'somewhere', so there's a working flatten available :)

And if fixing the pragma is out of scope for core, then I agree/think that fixing SPDX should also be out of scope. Either flatten just means replace the imports with the file contents (+dedup) regardless.... or it means: create a flattened Solidity file (that should compile to the same code).
